bibl.title: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, June 21, 1921

div1.p: Fisher reports on an increase in malaria attributed to dam impoundment in South Carolina.

div1.head: Letter from L.M. Fisher to Henry Rose Carter, June 21, 1921
div1.opener:
COPY
Columbia, S. C., June 2, 1921.
Dr. H. R. Carter, Asst. Surgeon General
U.S. Public Health Service
2121 California Street, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
During the summer of 1919, the
Southern Power Company flooded a large portion
of the Wateree river valley with a dam built near
Camden. Although the Company seems to have taken
some precaution in cleaning the edges of the pond,
the flooding evidently greatly increased the pre-
valence of malaria in the surrounding country.
We recently made a house to house census near
Longtown, Fairfield County, which disclosed the
following results:

Of the 319 people living there in
1921, 305 lived there in 1920 and 304 in 1919. The
average length of residence for the whole popula-
tion was eleven and a half years. The average dis-
tance of the seventy-nine houses visited from high
water mark was 1.44 miles. Nineteen houses were
one mile away or less than two miles distant; eight
were two miles but less than three miles distant,
and fourteen were at a distance of three or three
and a half miles, making forty-one houses one mile
or more from high water. Ten other houses were found to
-2-
have been vacated. These distances are estimated
distances and are subject to some corrections.

Mayne was here week before last and left
us under the impression that he would establish a
laboratory at Rock Hill, where he could study
normal conditions on this country and compare them
with conditions in the Wateree. Since then, I
have had some letters from him, in which he speaks
of being transferred. He has, however, requested
me to arrange for a room in which he can establish h
his laboratory. Whether Mayne will make any studies
or not, I think we will be able to gather some more
data during the summer, with reference to the
Wateree.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, L.M. Fisher
Associate Sanitary Engineer.
